com.biorecorder.edflib

Class EdfWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.biorecorder.edflib.EdfWriter
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    EdfFileWriter, EdfFilter

    public abstract class EdfWriter
extends java.lang.Object
    This abstract class is the superclass of all classes representing an output stream of DataRecords. An output stream accepts a digital DataRecord and send (write) it to some sink.

    To write data samples to the stream we must set a HeaderInfo object with the configuration information. Only after that data samples could be written correctly.

    We may write digital or physical samples. Every physical (floating point) sample will be converted to the corresponding digital (int) one using physical maximum, physical minimum, digital maximum and digital minimum of the signal.

    • Method Detail

      • setHeader

        public void setHeader(HeaderInfo headerInfo)
               throws java.io.IOException
        Sets a HeaderInfo object with the configuration information. This function MUST be called before writing any data.
        Parameters:
        headerInfo - - HeaderInfo object describing DataRecords structure
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • getHeader

        public HeaderInfo getHeader()
        Gets the HeaderInfo object with the configuration information.
        Returns:
        the object containing EDF/BDF header information

      • writeDigitalSamples

        public abstract void writeDigitalSamples(int[] digitalSamples)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
        Write "raw" digital (integer) samples from the given array to the stream/file.

        Call this method for every signal (channel) of the stream/file. The order is important! When there are 4 signals, the order of calling this method must be:
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        ... etc.

        Number of samples for every signal: n_i = (sample frequency of the signal_i) * (duration of DataRecord).

        The entire DataRecord (data pack) containing digital data from all signals also can be placed in one array and written at once.

        Parameters:
        digitalSamples - digital samples belonging to some signal or entire DataRecord
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writePhysicalSamples

        public void writePhysicalSamples(double[] physicalSamples)
                          throws java.io.IOException
        Write physical samples (uV, mA, Ohm) from the given array to the stream/file.

        Call this method for every signal (channel) of the stream/file. The order is important! The physical samples will be converted to digital samples using the values of physical maximum, physical minimum, digital maximum and digital minimum of of the signal. When there are 4 signals, the order of calling this method must be:
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        ... etc.

        Number of samples for every signal: n_i = (sample frequency of the signal_i) * (duration of DataRecord).

        The entire DataRecord (data pack) containing physical data from all signals also can be placed in one array and written at once.

        Parameters:
        physicalSamples - physical samples belonging to some signal or entire DataRecord
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • close

        public abstract void close()
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Closes this Edf/Bdf writer and releases any system resources associated with it. This writer may no longer be used for writing DataRecords. This method MUST be called after finishing writing DataRecords. Failing to do so will cause unnessesary memory usage and corrupted and incomplete data writing.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
